Award.AwardTitle: Homological Properties of Commutative Rings and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, several questions in commutative algebra will be studied. They are concrete statements about homological properties of rings and modules, but have unexpected and intriguing connections to other areas of mathematics. One part of the project proposes to investigate the vanishing behavior of Ext and Tor functors over Noetherian rings. Better understanding of such behavior can be used to attack a diverse set of problems such as Gabber 's conjecture about Picard groups of punctured spectra of complete intersections, or the existence of non-commutative resolution of singularities. Other topics include classification of subcategories of maximal Cohen-Macaulay modules, solving equations in the semi-ring of vector bundles on algebraic varieties and regularity of Stanley-Reisner ideals associated to simplicial complexes.

Commutative algebra deals with some of the most ubiquitous objects in mathematics, such as sets of equations in several variables. It has both natural and deep connections to fields such as algebraic and arithmetic geometry, number theory, representation theory and combinatorics. Such characteristics allow one to phrase many interesting questions at the front of modern research in the form accessible to even early graduate students. Many topics proposed in this project are about such connections, and their investigation are especially suitable for training and collaboration between young researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research deals with questions in commutative algeba. This branch of pure mathematics studies algebaic nature of systems of polynomial equations. One novel feature of the project is to formulate and study subtle invariants to measure the complexities of such systems using a number of different techniques: homological, categorical, geometric. How these invariants connect to each other, despite having very diverse origins, are also extremely interesting and was a foucs of this project.

The research proposed has resulted in more than 10 publications by the PI and collaborators, and it is still producing results. The most interesting feature is that many of the results were obtained as a combination of efforts by international researchers in different areas: commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, non-commutative algebra, combinatorics.

For example, one striking result was that system of equation with mild singularities (close to having a smooth graph), can be detected using homological properties of certain endomorpshim rings (a generalized concept of matrices space). 

The diverse nature of this research lead to many training and educational opportunities. Almost half of the publications were collaborations with postdocs  and  students. The PI  also taught a summer course at Dalhousie University for advanced undergraduate and beginning graduate students on homological algbera with a view towards the concepts and examples being investigated by our project.
